image.altText: A boy and his dad smiling together while on a mountain.

props.synopsis: Charlie Stevens, son of SA Police Commissioner Grant Stevens, is on life support in hospital after a crash south of Adelaide.

title.children: SA Police Commissioner's son suffers 'irreversible brain injury' after crash south of Adelaide

image.altText: A close up headshot of a police officer

props.synopsis: The death of police officer Jason Doig from a shooting in regional South Australia has sent emergency services across the nation into grieving, but the town where he worked for a decade has felt the immense loss.

title.children: 'First person to put on a uniform': Officer killed in regional SA shooting a great loss to the community

image.altText: A graphic shows three figures in hoodies with a black octopus silhouette against a green background.

props.synopsis: Fake Australian banking apps that look like the genuine article are appearing on the internet. Test your knowledge and see if you can tell the real from the fake.

title.children: The story of how 'Octo' malware's tentacles are reaching phone screens across Australia

image.altText: HMAS Toowoomba

props.synopsis: Naval divers working to clear fishing nets from the HMAS Toowoomba’s propellers were forced to exit the water when a Chinese warship began operating its hull-mounted sonar, in an incident labelled "unsafe and unprofessional".

title.children: Australian naval personnel injured by sonar pulses from Chinese warship

image.altText: The SA Police logo next to flowers.

props.synopsis: A police officer has died and another is in hospital after a shooting at a rural property in South Australia's south-east. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: One police officer is dead, another is injured. Here's what we know about the shooting in regional SA

image.altText: An unidentifiable woman in a red shirt stands outside in a crowd of people

props.synopsis: In the space of 12 months, Natalia derailed her career, ended her relationship, spent $120,000 in savings and lost access to her kids. It started with an ADHD diagnosis.

title.children: Natalia started taking Ritalin. Then her career imploded and she lost access to her kids

image.altText: a couple stands under an umbrella overlooking the sydney harbour bridge as strom clouds brew

props.synopsis: After a near rainless September and October, and the prospect of the driest spring on record, November serves up a pleasant surprise: rain.

title.children: Major storm event on the horizon across Australia as El Niño takes a raincheck

image.altText: Kim Jong Un waves.

props.synopsis: Last year, stealing cryptocurrency became North Korea's primary form of foreign currency income.

title.children: North Korea was floundering under sanctions. Now it's making billions from stolen cryptocurrency

image.altText: Albanese and Dutton's heads in profile are aligned in the centre of the frame, Albanese scratching his neck.

props.synopsis: There has been considerable comment about a race to the bottom in politics this week. But Thursday proved an equally dark day for the way we make laws in Australia, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Thursday was a dark day for the way we make laws in Australia. What happened in Parliament must be recorded

image.altText: A girl with dark hair, wearing a blue school uniform stares into the camera, school girls blurred in background behind.

props.synopsis: From the streets, to the courts, to the halls of power — school strikes may look smaller but students are finding other ways to fight for climate action and a better future.

title.children: 'It's not just me': How an idea to ditch school sparked a global climate movement that's giving kids hope

image.altText: Man stands in front of a small crowd in sand dunes

props.synopsis: Ancestral remains repatriated from Britain have been reburied in a moving ceremony on Ngarrindjeri country in South Australia's Coorong — more than 100 years after they were taken.

title.children: A century after being taken to the UK, an ancestor's remains are returned to the sands of the Coorong

image.altText: A memorial with candles and flowers around a picture of Jeffrey.

props.synopsis: The family of Jeffrey Winmar have remembered the Indigenous father of one as "bright, happy and respectable". They want more answer on why he died days after he was arrested by police.

title.children: Victorian family calls for answers over Aboriginal man's death days after police arrest

image.altText: Vote Labor and Vote Greens signs at a prepolling booth.

props.synopsis: Voters in the historically safe Labor seat of former premier Daniel Andrews are back to the polls today to elect his replacement in Victoria's lower house.

title.children: Voters in Melbourne electorate head to polls to replace Daniel Andrews

image.altText: David McBride raises is hand in a triumphant pose as people hold signs of support behind him.

props.synopsis: The decision by whistleblower David McBride to plead guilty to leaking classified information to the media is a chilling reminder of the flaws in Australia's whistleblower protections, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: A whistleblower's guilty plea sends a chilling reminder

image.altText: A woman in high-vis clothing, looking on and leaning on a piece of equipment in an industrial building

props.synopsis: Iceland is no stranger to volcanic eruptions, but this 15km crack that opened in a tiny coastal town has experts warning a once-dormant danger zone has "come to life".

title.children: This town is enduring 1,000 earthquakes a day, but the real threat is still to come

image.altText: inside of a shopping mall where the roof has caved in with construction debris everywhere

props.synopsis: Six people have died and dozens injured after a magnitude 6.7 earthquake struck the southern Philippines.

title.children: Magnitude 6.7 earthquake hits southern Philippines

image.altText: A man drives a car

props.synopsis: Every day could be Yasser's last. But he doesn't have time to think about that. Everywhere he goes, desperate people need him. WARNING: Some readers might find the details and images in this story distressing.

title.children: As a paramedic in Gaza, Yasser has seen the worst of the worst. But one face haunts him

image.altText: A man in a purple jumper, handcuffed, being led by police.

props.synopsis: A man facing attempted murder and conspiracy to murder charges has been extradited to South Australia, following a long-running investigation into a violent attack at a Littlehampton home in 2017.

title.children: Man extradited to Adelaide over alleged attempted murder of axe attack victim

image.altText: Two crime scene investigators in white protective gear walks out of a house towards crime tape

props.synopsis: Police say they expect to charge a man with murder over the death of a woman who was found unconscious at an address near Port Augusta overnight.

title.children: Murder charge expected over death of woman near Port Augusta

image.altText: Five people are pictured, they look scared. One woman is holding a baby as she walks away with the group.

props.synopsis: Gazans in the south have been warned by Israel to "head to known shelters". Israel has allowed a "very minimal" amount of fuel into the enclave as the WHO warns of disease as winter sets in.

title.children: Displaced Gazans told to go further south as WHO and UN warn of disease, starvation

image.altText: Lady's hand holding cash over the till

props.synopsis: With cash and change now a 700-kilometre round trip away, community groups and businesses in Tom Price are donating, bartering and looking for any available solution after the town's bank branch closed.

title.children: Cash is still king for sporting clubs and volunteer committees. This is what happens when the bank leaves town

image.altText: Two men standing together facing the camera

props.synopsis: In a new book by a former Australian diplomat, the stories and struggles of LGBT workers in Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are documented.

title.children: 'You just took it': The inside story of DFAT's treatment of LGBT staff over the decades

image.altText: A person's thumb edges towards a Facebook app icon on a smartphone.

props.synopsis: Scammers are using multinational brands — including a food delivery company and beloved character Paddington Bear — in a bid to steal money from Australian Facebook users.

title.children: What the trail of crumbs left by celebrity scammers tells us about who they target

image.altText: Fans in a mostly empty grandstand, have their thumbs down in disapproval

props.synopsis: Formula 1's re-introduction to Las Vegas was laced with disappointment, as the first practice session had barely 10 minutes of action, and the second session was completed with no fans.

title.children: F1 fans in Las Vegas forced to leave track after seeing just 10 minutes of driving

image.altText: A woman in a pink shirt holds a baby with short spiky hair

props.synopsis: How hospitals approach the needs of a patient who is also breastfeeding can have a significant impact on both mum and bub, and most Australian hospitals aren't offering accredited support.

title.children: Sharni really wanted to breastfeed. But she wasn't supported when she was hospitalised

image.altText: A rugby union executive sits at a desk with a nameplate in front of him at a press conference.

props.synopsis: The internal war within Rugby Australia turns ugly, with chairman Hamish McLennan urged to quit by six of his own member unions.

title.children: 'We no longer have any trust': Rugby Australia chair McLennan urged to quit by his own unions

image.altText: A herd of cattle.

props.synopsis: Along a dirt road in Far North Queensland is a farm where prisoners are learning to care for animals. The agricultural skills they are acquiring will set them up for work when they're released.

title.children: This farm looks like any other, but there's a key difference — the animals here are looked after by prisoners

image.altText: A man in a light blue polo and glasses looks at the camera looking despondent.

props.synopsis: Andrew and his wife bought a block of land to build their forever home. Months after signing the contract, the couple were told their contract would be terminated because the financier of the development wanted the blocks to sell for a higher price.

title.children: Andrew's dream home was ripped out from under him. Now the government is trying to close the 'loophole' that allowed it to happen

image.altText: Para-athlete Dorna Longbut crosses the finish line first in a 100m race.

props.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's Dorna Longbut walked away from sport after her mother died and she suffered an injury that left her without the use of her left arm. But now she's thriving in para-athletics.

title.children: After a serious rugby league injury, Dorna Longbut is making her mark in para-sport

image.altText: A large underground metal construction is pictured as workers are walking over it wearing hardhats.

props.synopsis: Faced with the constant threat of Russian air strikes, officials in eastern Ukraine's Kharkiv region have begun building heavily fortified underground schools that will allow children to safely return to in-person studies.

title.children: Kharkiv builds underground schools to allow children to return to in-person studies as Russia keeps up attacks

image.altText: An illustration of a man with a grey beard holding the face of a young woman, whose skin is deathly white

props.synopsis: In Exquisite Corpse, award-winning Australian author Marija Peričić gives voice to the women caught up in a man's macabre obsession with a dead patient.

title.children: Romantic hero or coercive criminal? The man who lived with the corpse of the woman he loved

image.altText: Two men's doubles tennis player react after winning a match, one punching the air and the other waving at the crowd.

props.synopsis: Australian Matt Ebden is still in line to finish his best-ever doubles season as both an ATP Finals champion in Turin and the world number one ranking.

title.children: Aussie doubles ace Matt Ebden races into semis at ATP Finals

image.altText: A group of women in blue team shirts and pink hats hold wooden paddles and pose in front of canoes

props.synopsis: Shona Muckert relies on a wheelchair for many day-to-day activities but when it comes to competitive canoeing, her disability does not hold her back.

title.children: Double amputee makes triumphant return to the sport she loves at National Sprint Championships
